review.title: A Tabu Search Algorithm for the Multi-period Inspector Scheduling Problem
review.abstract: This paper introduces a multi-period inspector scheduling problem (MPISP), which is a new variant of the multi-trip vehicle routing problem with time windows (VRPTW). In the MPISP, each inspector is scheduled to perform a route in a given multi-period planning horizon. At the end of each period, each inspector is not required to return to the depot but has to stay at one of the vertices for recuperation. If the remaining time of the current period is insufficient for an inspector to travel from his/her current vertex $A$ to a certain vertex B, he/she can choose either waiting at vertex A until the start of the next period or traveling to a vertex C that is closer to vertex B. Therefore, the shortest transit time between any vertex pair is affected by the length of the period and the departure time. We first describe an approach of computing the shortest transit time between any pair of vertices with an arbitrary departure time. To solve the MPISP, we then propose several local search operators adapted from classical operators for the VRPTW and integrate them into a tabu search framework. In addition, we present a constrained knapsack model that is able to produce an upper bound for the problem. Finally, we evaluate the effectiveness of our algorithm with extensive experiments based on a set of test instances. Our computational results indicate that our approach generates high-quality solutions.

metadata.title: A Tabu Search Algorithm for the Multi-period Inspector Scheduling Problem

sections.text: This paper presents a problem of multiple scheduling by inspectors (MPISP), which is a new variant of the problem of multi-vehicle scheduling with time windows (VRPTW). MPISP provides that each inspector carries out a route within a given multi-line planning horizon. At the end of each period, each inspector is not obliged to return to the depot room, but must stay at one of the vertices to recover. If the remaining time of the current period is not sufficient for an inspector to get from his current vertice A to a specific vertice B, he / she can choose whether to wait at vertice A until the beginning of the next period or travel to a vertice C closer to the vertice B. Therefore, the shortest transit time between each vertice A is affected by the length of the period and departure time.

sections.heading: 5.1. Solution representation
sections.text: In Section 3, we have used the order of visited vertices to represent the problem solution (see Figure 3), but in our taboo search algorithm, we represent the route of each inspector through a sequence of serviced suppliers. For example, Figure 7 shows a solution that is exactly the same as the one in Figure 3. Routes r1, r2, r3 and r4 include the serviced suppliers, and the ejection pool U contains the remaining suppliers. All waypoints are not displayed in this solution representation and there may be waypoints and / or fractions between two consecutive serviced suppliers.

sections.heading: 5.2. Fitness function
sections.text: The taboo search algorithm ranks solutions based on a fitness function. It is natural to define the fitness value of a solution depending on the total workload that P (S), 14 Algorithm 2 Framework of taboo search algorithms each have the same value of P (S). To distinguish further solutions, two further measures of D (S) and F (S), 14 Algorithm 2 Framework of taboo search algorithms each have the same value of P (S), 2: best ← S0 and S (suppliers) S0; 3: i (suppliers) vi; 4: while i ≤ maxPerturbation do 5: S ² the best solution is found by local search (S); 6: S ² EPA (S) 7: if S ′ is better than best then 8: best ← S0 and i (suppliers) vi; 4: while i ≤ maxPerturbation do 5: end.

sections.heading: 5.3. Initialization
sections.text: We get a first workable solution for the taboo search algorithm with the help of algorithm 3. This algorithm first creates workable solutions for Ninit using the function init (see algorithm 4) and then selects the best solution as the initial solution. In each iteration of init, we first calculate the shortest runtime stri from the tail of each route r to each rogue supplier vi. if vi cannot be workably appended to the tail of r, we set st r i = + ∞. Next, we calculate the ratio of Stri to di and set ρi to the minimum ratio of vi across all routes (see algorithm 4, line 11). If the value of ρi is positively infinite, i.e. vi cannot be appended to the tail of a route, we remove vi from U. Finally, we sort all suppliers in U by increasing the value of ρi and moving the k supplier from U to the tail of the route, which has a value of r > / s.

sections.heading: 5.4. Local search with tabu moves
sections.text: The pseudocode of the local taboo-step search procedure is contained in Algorithm5. In the following context of this subsection, all the main components of this procedure are presented, including neighborhood structure, taboo list, aspiration and termination criteria. 17Algorithm 3 function best init.1: Initialize S0 = ∅; 2: while i ≤ Ninit do 3: S = init (); 4: if S is better than S0, then 5: S0 ← S; 6: End if7: i = i + 1; 8: End while9: Return S0.

sections.heading: 5.4.1. Neighborhood structure
sections.text: The neighborhood structure is one of the most important components determining the size of the search space and the quality of the final solution. Our taboo search algorithms include five neighborhood operations adapted from the classic operations for the VRPTW (Bra � ysy and Gendreau, 2005), namely 2-Opt, Or-Opt, 2-Opt solution, Relocate and Exchange. Wetreat the Ejection Pool as a Dummy Route, which includes all unused vendors. Compared to their classic counterparts, these customized operations require more computational efforts to verify the feasibility of the resulting solution and update the earliest and latest arrival times to the affected vendors. Figure 8 illustrates the 2-Opt and Opt operations. We assume that we have specified the earliest and latest arrival times (eai and lai) at each vendor. The earliest departure time (edi) of each vendor can be easily derived if ceil (and ai).

sections.heading: 5.4.2. Tabu list, aspiration and termination
sections.text: The taboo search algorithm uses one or more taboo lists to prevent the search process from getting caught in local Optima. In our implementation, the taboo list stores edges created within the previous iterations. A move is considered taboo if it attempts to remove the edges in the taboo list. The taboo restriction can be lifted if the aspiration criterion is met. In particular, we allow the taboo moves to be performed if the solutions they yield are better than the currently best solution S ′. The solutions created by non-taboo moves or aspiration are referred to as permissible neighbors. All permissible movements are stored in a candidate list and sorted according to the fitness values of their resulting solutions. The best candidate is performed to generate the next established solution.We terminate the local search procedure if maxLocalIter consecutive iterations are unable to improve S.

sections.heading: 5.5. Ejection pool
sections.text: The ejection pool has previously been used in algorithms to reduce the number of ejections for some routing problems (see, for example, Lim and Zhang (2007); Nagata and Bra � ysy (2009); Cheang and al. (2012). Our ejection pool algorithm (EPA) is presented in Algorithm 6. The initial solution of this algorithm is the best solution found by a local ejection process. Since S � is a local optimum, no supplier in the ejection pool can be practically introduced in S �. EPA generates a candidate solution based on S � for each of the unused suppliers through an ejection process. If the best candidate solution is S � over S �, then S � is continuously updated.For each u � U, we evaluate their insertion positions using function c (i, u, y �), namely the highest position of the two consecutive feeders.

sections.heading: 5.6. Perturbation
sections.text: Our fault procedure (malfunction) randomly removes some suppliers from the S ² solution, following the rule that suppliers with lower workloads have a greater chance of being removed. Considering a S ′ solution, we sort the served suppliers in an innon-decreasing order of workloads and compile a supplier list (v1, v2,., vn ′). The probability of removing the k ′ supplier is determined by the following factors: pmin + (pmin − pmin) · kn ′, (6), where pmin and pmax are satisfactory parameters (see rows 4 - 13, algorithm S ²). It implies that the supplier with higher workload is less likely to be excluded. The taboo search algorithm performs at least maxperturbationsiterations (see rows 4 - 13, algorithm P ²). We store the best solution S ² within each iteration in a listing, effectively displaying the solutions with the WS ² (WS ²) values.

sections.heading: 6. Upper bound
sections.text: The solutions generated by our taboo search algorithms are lower limits to MPISPs. In this section, we construct a limited model to create an upper limit for MPISP; this model is developed by Lau et al. (2003).25The time windows of all suppliers can be adjusted on the basis of the following guidelines: for a supplier i, if the opening time of his window is within the next period, i.e. it is impossible to complete his service during that period, i.e., bp − ei < si, then the real starting time for suppliers i, should be the opening time of the next period.

sections.heading: 7. Computational experiments
sections.text: Our Tabu Search (TS) algorithm was encoded in C + + and compiled with the gcc 4.6.1compiler and tested on a Dell server with an Intel Xeon E5430 2.66GHz CPU, 8 GBRAM and a Linux-CentOS 5.0 64-bit operating system. It was configured with preset parameter settings: η = 1.0, Ninit = 100, α1 = 5, maxPerturbation = 4, maxLocalIter = 200, 0 = 100, β1 = 0.6, β2 = β3 = β4 = 0.4, β5 = 0.2, pmin = 0.05, pmax = 0.30, p х = 0.1 and Nmax = 5. MPISP is reduced to the traditional TOPTW when w = 1 and Q = + 3, β3 = β4. In our experiments, we first applied the TS logic algorithm to the TOPTW instances and compared the results, which were performed in 2009 because of the labs.

sections.heading: 7.1. Test instances
sections.text: We looked at the TOPTW instances that can be accessed in Vansteenwegen et al. (2009); Hu andLim (2014), which can be accessed at http: / / www.mech.kuleuven.be / en / cib / op. Hu andLim (2014) classified these instances into two categories, namely "INST-M" and "OPT"; instances in the category INST-M have unknown optimal solution values, while the optimal solution values of instances in the category OPT given.28The TOPTW instances in the category INST-M were constructed by Montemanni and Gam-bardella (2009), based on the OPTW instances, using the number of vehicles removed from the group OPTW {1, 2, 4} These OPTW instances in the category INST-M were Vs VP's VP's and Salani (2009) using 56 Solomons VRPTW-1 instances (Solomons VP's VP's VP's VP's RP's VP's RP's VP's RP's RP's VP's VP's RP's VP's VP's RP's VP's VP's RP's VP's VP's RP's VP's VP's VP's RP's (2009).

sections.heading: 7.2. Results for the TOPTW instances
sections.text: To evaluate the performance of our algorithm based on TOPTW instances, we looked at the following four state-of-the-art algorithms in our comparisons: • ILS: the iterated local search algorithm by Vansteenwegen et al. (2012). • SSA: the slow version of the simulated annealing algorithm by Lin and Yu (2012). • GVNS: the LP-based granular search algorithm by Labadieet al. • I3CH: the iterative three-component heuristics by Hu and Lim (2012).

sections.heading: 7.3. Analysis of components
sections.text: Since our ETS algorithm consists of three main components, namely the local search with Tabumoves (EP), the Ejection Pool (EP) algorithm and the perturbation (PPER) method, it is important to examine the performance of these components. In the experiments, we looked at the combinations LS + EP, LS + PER, EP + PER and LS + EP + PER and 50 TOPTWinstances generated from pr01 - pr10. Table 3 shows the average performance of these four combinations. For each test instance, we calculated a ratio that corresponds to the average gain over ten EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EP EEEP EEEEEEEEEEEEEEEP EEEEEEP EEEEP EEEP EP EEEP EEEEEEEP EEEEEEEEEEEEEEEP EEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEE

sections.heading: 7.4. Results for the MPISP instances
sections.text: column shows the upper limit of each instance derived from the constraint pinsack model (see section 6). Each block corresponds to a value of w and contains the maximum workload Max workload, the average workload Ave. workload, and the average computation time Ave. time over the ten executions. Since the MPISP is a new problem, there is no existing algorithm tailored to it. Consequently, we cannot compare our taboo search algorithm with other approaches. The test instances and computation results given in this article can serve as benchmarks for future researchers on this problem. Theoretically, the optimal solution value of an instance with w = d cannot be compared to that of the same instance with w = kd, where k is an integral number. This is because we can always measure an optimal solution for an instance with w = d.

sections.heading: 8. Conclusion
sections.text: This paper presents a problem of inspector planning, where a number of inspectors are sent to complete a series of inspection applications at different locations within a multi-tiered planning horizon. At the end of each period, each inspector does not have to return to the depot, but must stay at one of the inspection sites for recovery. First, we investigated the way in which the shortest duration between any locations can be calculated if the work periods are taken into account. Next, we introduced several local search operators adapted to classical VRPTW operators and integrated these adapted operators into a taboo search framework. In addition, we presented a limited knapsack model capable of generating an upper limit for the MPISP. Finally, we evaluated the algorithm base on 370 TOPTW instances and 672 MPISP instances. The experimental results reported in this study demonstrate the effectiveness of our algorithm and can serve as a measure of the number of time windows that are widely used in practice.

, 2009) and the multiple trip vehicle routing problem (MTVRP) (Battarra et al., 2009). However, the MPISP is quite different from the PVRP and MTVRP. In the PVRP, each customer requires a certain number of visits within the planning horizon, and two types of decisions are involved in the planning, namely determining the visit days for each customer and the routing plan for each time period. The PVRP and MTVRP both require that each vehicle must return to the depot at the end of each period. Another defining characteristic of the MPISP is the consideration of multiple working periods. Working hour regulations have recently received increasing attention from some researchers studying vehicle routing problems. Savelsbergh and Sol (1998) proposed a dynamic

The OPHS is a variant of the traveling salesperson problem with hotel selection (TSPHS) (Vansteenwegen et al., 2012; Castro et al., 2013), which aims to serve all vertices with the minimum number of connected trips and the minimum total travel distance.

The OPHS is a variant of the traveling salesperson problem with hotel selection (TSPHS) (Vansteenwegen et al., 2012; Castro et al., 2013), which aims to serve all vertices with the minimum number of connected trips and the minimum total travel distance.

Xu et al. (2003) applied column generation based solution approaches to solve a pickup and delivery vehicle routing problem that involves a set of practical complications, such as heterogeneous vehicles, last-in-first-out loading and unloading operations, pickup and delivery time windows, and working hour restrictions by the United States Department of Transportation.
Similarly, Goel (2009, 2010) and Kok et al. (2010) investigated combined vehicle routing and driver scheduling problems under the European Union regulations for drivers.

(2013) proposed an inspector scheduling problem which is very similar to our problem.

Tabu search algorithm has been successfully applied to a wide variety of routing and scheduling problems, such as the classical VRP (Gendreau et al., 1994; Toth and Vigo, 2003), the VRPTW (Chiang and Russell, 1997; Gordeau et al.

Tabu search algorithm has been successfully applied to a wide variety of routing and scheduling problems, such as the classical VRP (Gendreau et al., 1994; Toth and Vigo, 2003), the VRPTW (Chiang and Russell, 1997; Gordeau et al.
, 1994; Toth and Vigo, 2003), the VRPTW (Chiang and Russell, 1997; Gordeau et al., 2001), the three-dimensional loading capacitated VRP (Zhu et al.
, 2001), the three-dimensional loading capacitated VRP (Zhu et al., 2012), the job-shop scheduling problem (Barnes and
Chambers, 1995) and the nurse rostering problem (Burke et al., 2003).

Our tabu search algorithm employs several operations adapted from classical operations for the VRPTW, namely 2-opt, Or-opt, 2-opt∗, Relocate and Exchange (Bräysy and Gendreau, 2005), and an ejection pool (Lim and Zhang, 2007; Nagata and Bräysy, 2009).

In this section, we construct a constrained knapsack model to produce an upper bound for the MPISP; this model is motivated by Lau et al. (2003). 25
Next, we conducted experiments on the MPISP instances generated from the Solomon’s VRPTW instances (Solomon, 1987).

In our experiments, we first applied the TS algorithm to the TOPTW instances and compared the results with the recent results reported in Vansteenwegen et al. (2009); Lin and Yu (2012); Labadie et al.

Hu and Lim (2014) classified these instances into two categories, namely “INST-M” and “OPT”; the instances in category INST-M have unknown optimal solution values while the optimal solution values of the instances in category OPT are given.
These OPTW instances were designed by Righini and Salani (2009) using 56 Solomon’s VRPTW instances (Solomon, 1987) and 20 Cordeau’s multi-depot VRP (MDVRP) instances (Cordeau et al.
These OPTW instances were designed by Righini and Salani (2009) using 56 Solomon’s VRPTW instances (Solomon, 1987) and 20 Cordeau’s multi-depot VRP (MDVRP) instances (Cordeau et al., 1997).
The TOPTW instances in category INST-M were constructed by Montemanni and Gambardella (2009) based on the OPTW instances by considering the number of vehicles taken from set {1, 2, 3, 4}.

The TOPTW instances in category INST-M were constructed by Montemanni and Gambardella (2009) based on the OPTW instances by considering the number of vehicles taken from set {1, 2, 3, 4}. These OPTW instances were designed by Righini and Salani (2009) using 56 Solomon’s VRPTW instances (Solomon, 1987) and 20 Cordeau’s multi-depot VRP (MDVRP) instances (Cordeau et al.

These OPTW instances were designed by Righini and Salani (2009) using 56 Solomon’s VRPTW instances (Solomon, 1987) and 20 Cordeau’s multi-depot VRP (MDVRP) instances (Cordeau et al., 1997). The Solomon’s VRPTW instances, each containing 100 customers, are divided into six groups, namely C1 (c101 – c109), C2 (c201 – c208), R1 (r101 – r112), R2 (r201 – r211), RC1 (rc101 – rc108) and RC2 (rc201 – rc208). The numbers of customers in the MDVRP instances (pr01 – pr20) range from 48 to 288. The TOPTW instances were obtained from the VRPTW or MDVRP instances by the following two steps: (1) set the profit collected at each customer to be the demand of this customer, and (2) remove the vehicle capacity restriction. The instances in category OPT are the same as the instances in category INST-M except for the number of vehicles available. Vansteenwegen et al. (2009) designed the instances in category OPT by setting the number of vehicles in each aforementioned TOPTW instance except for pr11 – pr20 to the number of vehicles appearing in the solution of the corresponding VRPTW instance.
• ILS: the iterated local search algorithm by Vansteenwegen et al. (2009).
• GVNS: the LP-based granular variable neighborhood search algorithm by Labadie et al. (2012).
• I3CH: the iterative three-component heuristic (I3CH) by Hu and Lim (2014).
Since Labadie et al. (2012) did not report the best solution value in their article, we filled the corresponding cells with “N/A” and ignored these cells when calculating the overall average ratio.

metadata.abstractText: This paper introduces a multi-period inspector scheduling problem (MPISP), which is a new variant of the multi-trip vehicle routing problem with time windows (VRPTW). In the MPISP, each inspector is scheduled to perform a route in a given multi-period planning horizon. At the end of each period, each inspector is not required to return to the depot but has to stay at one of the vertices for recuperation. If the remaining time of the current period is insufficient for an inspector to travel from his/her current vertex A to a certain vertex B, he/she can choose either waiting at vertex A until the start of the next period or traveling to a vertex C that is closer to vertex B. Therefore, the shortest transit time between any vertex pair is affected by the length of the period and the departure time. We first describe an approach of computing the shortest transit time between any pair of vertices with an arbitrary departure time. To solve the MPISP, we then propose several local search operators adapted from classical operators for the VRPTW and integrate them into a tabu search framework. In addition, we present a constrained knapsack model that is able to produce an upper bound for the problem. Finally, we evaluate the effectiveness of our algorithm with extensive experiments based on a set of test instances. Our computational results indicate that our approach generates high-quality solutions.
